{{distinguish|Antisec Movement}} [[File:AntiSec.svg|thumb|An image that [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] has used to represent the operation; it contains elements of symbols used to represent both Anonymous and [[LulzSec]].]] '''Operation Anti-Security''', also referred to as '''Operation AntiSec''' or '''#AntiSec''', is a series of [[hacker (computer security)|hacking]] attacks performed by members of hacking group [[LulzSec]] and BlackSec, the group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]], and others inspired by the announcement of the operation. LulzSec performed the earliest attacks of the operation, with the first against the [[Serious Organised Crime Agency]] on 20 June 2011. Soon after, the group released information taken from the servers of the [[Arizona Department of Public Safety]]; Anonymous would later release information from the same agency two more times. An offshoot of the group calling themselves LulzSecBrazil launched attacks on numerous websites belonging to the [[Government of Brazil]] and the energy company [[Petrobras]]. LulzSec claimed to retire as a group, but on 18 July they reconvened to hack into the websites of British newspapers ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' and ''[[The Times]]'', posting a fake news story of the death of the publication's owner [[Rupert Murdoch]].
Anonymous released their first cache of the operation on 27 June 2011, taken from an anti-[[cyberterrorism]] program run by the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] and [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]. They continued attacks on the Arizona government. They also launched attacks against the governments of [[Brazil]], [[Zimbabwe]], and [[Tunisia]]. Their most recent attacks have been against large corporations, [[NATO]], and various United States law enforcement websites. Anonymous has used the stolen credit card numbers of police officers to make unauthorized donations to various causes. Others have also committed hacks in the name of the operation, including a hack into the [[Fox News]] [[Twitter]] account to post a false news story about the assassination of [[President of the United States]] [[Barack Obama]] and attacks on the websites of government entities in various countries. The groups involved have published sensitive government and corporate information, as well as the email addresses, names, and social security numbers, and credit card numbers of website users.
[[Law enforcement]] has launched investigations into many of the attacks committed as part of Operation AntiSec. At least seven arrests have been made in connection to activities related to the operation, including the arrests of two purported LulzSec members, a man who provided LulzSec with security vulnerability information, and four alleged members of AntiSec NL, a group inspired by the operation.
==Background== The [[LulzSec]] hacking group formed in May 2011 and came to international prominence after hacking the websites of the [[Public Broadcasting Service]], [[Sony]], and the [[United States Senate]].<ref name=twsj>{{cite news|last1=Morse|last2=Sherr|first1=Andrew|first2=Ian|title=For Some Hackers, The Goal Is Just To Play A Prank|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110605-702801.html|accessdate=6 June 2011|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|page=B1|date=6 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Peter | last = Svensson | title = Parting is such tweet sorrow for hacker group | date = 27 June 2011 | publisher = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | url = http://www.smh.com.au/technology/security/parting-is-such-tweet-sorrow-for-hacker-group-20110626-1glos.html#ixzz1QSL6wvEC | work = The Sydney Morning Herald | accessdate = 29 June 2011}}</ref> Initially, the group claimed to hack "for the lulz" and to enjoy the chaos that follows their intrusions.<ref name=reasons>{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=David|title=Three Reasons to Fear Lulzsec: Sites, Skills, and Slant|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2387219,00.asp|accessdate=20 June 2011|newspaper=[[PC Magazine]]|date=19 June 2011|agency=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zZnbgTxl|archivedate=20 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=ind>{{cite news|last=Taylor|first=Jerome|title=Who are the group behind this week's CIA hack?|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/who-are-the-group-behind-this-weeks-cia-hack-2298430.html|accessdate=20 June 2011|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=16 June 2011|agency=Independent Print Limited|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zZlxA19Y|archivedate=20 June 2011|location=London}}</ref> However, on 20 June 2011, the group announced that they were teaming up with hacking collective [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] for a series of attacks they dubbed Operation Anti-Security or Operation AntiSec. The press release accompanying the beginning of the operation called for supporters to steal and publish classified government documents under the name AntiSec. Major banks and corporations were also mentioned as potential targets.<ref name=aussie>{{cite news|last=Ross|first=Nick|title=Lulzsec teams up with Anonymous|url=http://www.abc.net.au/technology/articles/2011/06/20/3248520.htm|accessdate=20 June 2011|newspaper=[[ABC Online]]|date=20 June 2011|agency=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]}}</ref> Though LulzSec disbanded as a group on 26 June 2011, members have been reported to be continuing the operation from within Anonymous.<ref name=newantisec>{{cite news|last=Olivarez-Giles|first=Nathan|title=AntiSec 'hackers without borders' claim new hack on Arizona state police|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2011/06/antisec-hackers-leak-files-said-to-be-from-arizona-state-police.html|accessdate=30 June 2011|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=29 June 2011|agency=[[Tribune Company]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zq3OxQQv|archivedate=30 June 2011|location=[[Los Angeles]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first1=Joe|last1=Weisenthal|title=Notorious Hacker Group LulzSec Just Announced That It's Finished |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/lulzsec-finished-2011-6|accessdate=25 June 2011|newspaper=[[Business Insider]]|date=25 June 2011|agency=Silicon Alley Insider|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ziS1EJcn|archivedate=25 June 2011}}</ref>
The groups involved claim that the operation aims to protest government censorship and monitoring of the internet.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=Operation Anti-Security: Anonymous yet to act while LulzSec rampage|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/167639/20110622/lulzsec-lulz-security-anonymous-operation-anti-security-anti-sec-hacked-cleary-ryan-arrest-attack.htm|accessdate=24 June 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=22 June 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zfn4uYd2|archivedate=24 June 2011|location=New York City}}</ref> LulzSec members also mention ending what they believe are corrupt [[racial profiling]] and [[copyright law]]s as a goal of the operation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Watts|first=Susan|title=Newsnight online 'chat' with Lulz Security hacking group|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-13912836|accessdate=30 June 2011|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=24 June 2011|agency=[[BBC]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zokiC5Tk|archivedate=30 June 2011|location=[[London]]}}</ref> The [[War on Drugs]] has also been given as a reason for particular hacks.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bright|first=Peter|title=LulzSec's first Operation Anti-Security release: Arizona DPS|url=https://arstechnica.com/security/news/2011/06/lulzsecs-first-operation-anti-security-release-arizona-dps.ars|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[Ars Technica]]|date=25 June 2011|agency=[[Condé Nast Publications]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zwTGpAGZ|archivedate=5 July 2011}}</ref> In contrast, [[USA Today]] described the operation as [[cyberwarfare]] targeting governments and large corporations.<ref name=USAToday>{{cite news|last=Acohido|first=Byron|title=LulzSec, Anonymous declare war against governments, corporations|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/technologylive/post/2011/06/lulzsec-anonymous-declare-war-against-governments-corporations/1|accessdate=20 June 2011|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=20 June 2011|agency=[[Gannett Company]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zaKQaWdZ|archivedate=20 June 2011|location=[[McLean, Virginia]]}}</ref>
==LulzSec activities== LulzSec launched the first attacks of the operation against the [[Serious Organised Crime Agency]], the national [[law enforcement agency]] of the [[United Kingdom]] that handles [[cybercrime]]. The group launched a [[Denial-of-service attack|distributed denial-of-service attack]] against the agency's website on 20 June, taking it offline for only a few minutes.<ref>{{cite news|last=Meyer|first=David|title=LulzSec claims Soca hack|url=http://www.zdnet.co.uk/blogs/communication-breakdown-10000030/lulzsec-claims-soca-hack-10022772/|accessdate=20 June 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=20 June 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zaPT1ekX|archivedate=20 June 2011}}</ref> On the same day, they knocked the website of the [[Jianhua District]] in [[Qiqihar]], [[China]] offline.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ragan|first=Steve|title=LulzSec and Anonymous: Hunting for skeletons hidden in closets|url=http://www.thetechherald.com/article.php/201125/7295/LulzSec-and-Anonymous-Hunting-for-skeletons-hidden-in-closets|accessdate=21 June 2011|newspaper=[[The Tech Herald]]|date=21 June 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zbHJFF18|archivedate=21 June 2011}}</ref>
On 23 June, the group released a large cache of documents taken from the servers of the [[Arizona Department of Public Safety]]. The release, titled "chinga la migra", roughly translating to "fuck the [[border guard|border patrol]]", including email addresses and passwords and hundreds of documents marked "sensitive" or "for official use only".<ref>{{cite news|last=Aamoth|first=Doug|title=LulzSec Claims Breach Against Arizona Law Enforcement|url=http://techland.time.com/2011/06/23/lulzsec-claims-breach-against-arizona-law-enforcement/|accessdate=23 June 2011|newspaper=Techland (Time)|date=23 June 2011}}</ref> The group claimed that they did so in retaliation for the passage of [[Arizona SB 1070]], a law they saw as leading to unjust racial profiling.<ref>{{cite news|last=Tsotsis|first=Alexia|title=LulzSec Releases Arizona Law Enforcement Data In Retaliation For Immigration Law|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/06/23/lulzsec-releases-arizona-law-enforcement-data-in-retaliation-for-immigration-law/|accessdate=23 June 2011|newspaper=TechCrunch|date=23 June 2011}}</ref> Arizona complained that the release of officer identities and the personal information of their families could put them and their families in danger and gave those exposed security protection. In response, they mobilized the [[Arizona Counter Terrorism Information Center]] and locked remote access of Department of Public Safety email accounts.<ref>{{cite web|title=DPS Victim of Cyber Attack|url=http://www.azdps.gov/Media/News/View/?p=316|work=Press Releases|publisher=[[Arizona Department of Public Safety]]|accessdate=30 June 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zonSmr0O|archivedate=30 June 2011|location=[[Phoenix, Arizona]]|date=27 June 2011}}</ref>
On 25 June 2011, the group released what they described as their last dump of the operation. The release contained a large amount of information from varied sources. Included was information from numerous companies, including half a [[gigabyte]] of data from telecommunications company [[AT&T]] and [[IP address]]es from [[Sony]], [[Viacom]], [[Disney]], [[EMI]], and [[NBC Universal]].<ref name=whittaker>{{cite news|last=Whittaker|first=Zack|title=LulzSec disbands: Final cache includes AT&T internal data and 750,000 user accounts|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/igeneration/lulzsec-disbands-final-cache-includes-at-t-internal-data-and-750000-user-accounts/11134|accessdate=26 June 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=25 June 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zijhtzV4|archivedate=26 June 2011}}</ref><ref name=greenberg>{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Andy|title=LulzSec Says Goodbye, Dumping NATO, AT&T, Gamer Data|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/andygreenberg/2011/06/25/lulzsec-says-goodbye-dumping-nato-att-gamer-data/|accessdate=26 June 2011|newspaper=[[Forbes Magazine]]|date=25 June 2011|agency=[[Forbes]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ziimGwf5|archivedate=26 June 2011|location=New York City}}</ref> The AT&T portion included information pertaining to the release of the [[4G]] LTE, 90,000 personal phones used by [[IBM]], and the development of the [[iPad 3]].<ref name=greenberg/><ref>{{cite news|last=Sin|first=Gloria|title=LulzSec leaked AT&T LTE rollout plans and iPad 3 rumor|url=http://asia.cnet.com/crave/lulzsec-leaked-atandt-lte-rollout-plans-and-ipad-3-rumor-62209544.htm|accessdate=4 July 2011|newspaper=[[CNET]]|date=28 June 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zw204VrM|archivedate=4 July 2011}}</ref> It also contained over 750,000 usernames and password combinations, including 200,000 from hackforums.net, 12,000 from the [[NATO]] online bookstore, 500,000 from the online [[video game]] [[Battlefield Heroes]], 50,000 from various video game forums, and 29 from [[Ireland|Irish]] [[private investigation]] company Priority Investigations.<ref name=greenberg/> Finally, an internal manual for [[AOL]] engineers and a screencapture of the [[United States Navy]] website [[navy.mil]] after being vandalized.<ref name=greenberg/>
On 22 June, an offshoot of the group calling themselves LulzSecBrazil took down the website of the [[Government of Brazil]], brasil.gov.br, and the [[President of Brazil]], presidencia.gov.br.<ref>{{cite news|last=Emery|first=Daniel|title=LulzSec hits Brazilian websites|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-13878888|accessdate=22 June 2011|newspaper=BBC |date=22 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Clark|first=Jack|title=LulzSec takes down Brazil government sites|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-20073219-83/lulzsec-takes-down-brazil-government-sites/|accessdate=22 June 2011|newspaper=CNet|date=22 June 2011}}</ref> They also targeted the website of Brazilian energy company [[Petrobras]].<ref>{{cite news|last=McMillan|first=Robert|title=Brazilian Government, Energy Company Latest LulzSec Victims|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/230902/brazilian_government_energy_company_latest_lulzsec_victims.html|accessdate=22 June 2011|newspaper=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|date=22 June 2011|agency=[[International Data Group|IDG]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zdkR3nOy|archivedate=22 June 2011}}</ref> On 24 June, they claimed to publish access codes and passwords to the Petrobras website along with personnel profiles. However, the company denied that any information had been stolen, and the group removed the claim from their [[Twitter]] feed a few hours later.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rapoza|first=Kenneth|title=LulzSec Strikes Brazil Again; Petrobras Denies Being Hacked|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/kenrapoza/2011/06/25/lulzsec-strikes-brazil-again-petrobras-denies-being-hacked/|accessdate=26 June 2011|newspaper=[[Forbes Magazine]]|date=25 June 2011|agency=[[Forbes]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zjTPRtmX|archivedate=26 June 2011|location=New York City}}</ref> The group also published the personal information of [[President of Brazil]] [[Dilma Rousseff]] and [[Mayor of São Paulo]] [[Gilberto Kassab]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Lopez|first=Luciana|title=Hackers target Brazilian statistics agency|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/24/us-cybersecurity-brazil-hackers-idUSTRE75N2EK20110624|accessdate=26 June 2011|agency=Reuters |date=24 June 2011|author2=Brian Ellsworth|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zjTsNsY5|archivedate=26 June 2011|location=London|editor=Anthony Boadle}}</ref>
Despite claiming to have retired, on 18 July LulzSec hacked into the website of British newspaper ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]''.<ref name=Gayomail>{{cite news|last=Gayomail|first=Chris|title=LulzSec Hacks 'News of the World' and 'The Sun,' Plants Fake Murdoch Death Story|url=http://techland.time.com/2011/07/18/lulzsec-hacks-news-of-the-world-and-the-sun-plants-fake-murdoch-death-story/|accessdate=18 July 2011|newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=18 July 2011|agency=[[Time Inc.]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60HMwKM98|archivedate=18 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> The group redirected the newspaper's website to an also-hacked redesign website of another newspaper ''[[The Times]]'', altering the site to resemble ''The Sun'' and posting a fake story claiming that [[Rupert Murdoch]] had died after ingesting a fatal dose of [[palladium]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Rovzar|first=Chris|title=Website of Murdoch’s Sun Hacked|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/07/website_of_murdochs_sun_hacked.html|accessdate=18 July 2011|newspaper=[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]|date=18 July 2011|agency=New York Media Holdings|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60HMbQTWj|archivedate=18 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> They objected to the involvement of [[News Corporation]], the Murdoch-owned company that publishes ''The Sun'' and ''The Times'', in a large [[News International phone hacking scandal|phone hacking scandal]]. The hacked website also contained a webcomic depicting LulzSec deciding on and carrying out the attack.<ref name=Gayomail/><ref>{{cite web|title=Media moguls body discovered|url=http://www.new-times.co.uk/sun/|work=[[The Times]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=18 July 2011|author=Anonymous|authorlink=Anonymous (group)|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60HLGySde|archivedate=18 July 2011|location=[[London]]|date=18 July 2011}}</ref> The group later redirected ''The Sun'' website to their Twitter feed. News International released a statement regarding the attacks before having the page the statement appeared on also redirected to the LulzSec Twitter page and eventually taken offline. The group also released the names and phone numbers of a reporter for ''The Sun'' and two others associated with the newspaper and encouraged their supporters to call them.<ref name="cnetsun"/> The group further included an old email address and password of former News International executive [[Rebekah Brooks]].<ref name=cnetsun>{{cite news|last=Mills|first=Elinor|title=Hackers target Murdoch newspaper Web site|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-27080_3-20080503-245/hackers-target-murdoch-newspaper-web-site/|accessdate=19 July 2011|newspaper=[[CNET]]|date=18 July 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60HaIaC2J|archivedate=19 July 2011}}</ref> News Corporation took the websites offline as a precaution later in the day.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14196327|title=Lulz Security hackers target Sun website|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|location=[[London]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60IIHshJQ|archivedate=19 July 2011|date=18 July 2011|accessdate=19 July 2011}}</ref>
==Anonymous activities==
===June 2011=== On 27 June 2011, Anonymous published information relating to the Cyberterrorism Defense Initiative's Security and Network Training Initiative and National Education Laboratory program, or Sentinel program, an operation run by the United States [[Department of Homeland Security]] and [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]. The hack included information that the agency distributed in 2009 and contained resources on publicly available hacking software, a list of [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] bureau locations, details on counter-hacking tools, and form letters that law enforcement agencies used to obtain user details from [[internet service provider]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last=Reisinger|first=Don|title=Anonymous ready to roll in post-LulzSec world|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13506_3-20074610-17/anonymous-ready-to-roll-in-post-lulzsec-world/|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[CNET]]|date=27 June 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zx9CzH8u|archivedate=5 July 2011}}</ref>
On 28 June, the group released the second collection of documents stolen from the Arizona Department of Public Safety during Operation Anti-Security. Dubbed "Chinga la Migra Communique Dos", or "Fuck the Border Patrol Message Two", the data file contained the names, addresses, phone numbers, internet passwords, and [[social security number]]s of a dozen Arizona police officers. It also contained the emails, [[voicemail]]s, chat logs of some of them; in at least one instance it included sexually explicit photographs from one of the officer's girlfriends.<ref name=arizona2>{{cite news|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=LulzBoat Sails On: Anonymous Dumps More Arizona Data|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2387817,00.asp|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[PC Magazine]]|date=29 June 2011|agency=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zwDWqZkO|archivedate=5 July 2011}}</ref> Anonymous also claimed that the documents included officers forwarding racist chain emails, evidence of [[Police dog|K-9 unit]] officers using [[percocet]], and a [[Fraternal Order of Police]] member who is also a convicted [[sex offender]].<ref name=arizona2/> Anonymous noted that their motivation stemmed from a desire to make police officers "experience just a taste of the same kind of violence and terror they dish out on an every day basis."<ref name=arizona2/>
On the same day, the group released information obtained from various government sources. Government data from [[Anguilla]], passwords from servers belonging to the [[Government of Brazil]], the users of [[Zimbabwe]] government websites, and data from the [[Municipality of Mosman]] council were included.<ref name=Wilson/> The Mosman council dump included mainly publicly available information from the website as well as a not-publicly-available prototype version of the website that had not yet been launched.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Michael|title=Sydney council victim of AntiSec campaign|url=http://www.zdnet.com.au/sydney-council-victim-of-antisec-campaign-339317564.htm|accessdate=6 July 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=28 June 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxp1vmNv|archivedate=6 July 2011}}</ref> They claimed to also have access to all Zimbabwean government websites ending in gov.zw.<ref name=Wilson>{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Dean|title=Anonymous hacks Anguilla, Brazil, Zimbabwe and Australia governments|url=http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/2082148/anonymous-hacks-anguilla-brazil-zimbabwe-australia-governments|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[The Inquirer]]|date=28 June 2011|agency=[[Incisive Media]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zx8H3eux|archivedate=5 July 2011}}</ref> Most of the information and control were given through [[SQL injection]]. Anonymous claimed they targeted Brazil for what they saw as data manipulation and Zimbabwe for the controversial [[Zimbabwean presidential election, 2008|2008 Zimbabwean presidential election]].<ref name=viacom/> They also gained control of a website belonging to the [[Government of Tunisia]]. They replaced the webpage with a graphic representing Anonymous with text reading "The Internet is the last frontier and we will not let corrupt governments spoil it. We are Anonymous, We are LulzSec, We are People from around the world who are stepping in the name of freedom".<ref>{{cite news|title='Hacktivist' spree continues, Tunisian govt site latest target|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/224612/technology/hacktivist-spree-continues-tunisian-govt-site-latest-target|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[GMA News TV]]|date=28 June 2011|agency=[[GMA Network, Inc.]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxSQ2qht|archivedate=5 July 2011|location=[[Quezon City]]}}</ref> The release also included a file containing internal mapping of [[Viacom]] servers as well as passwords and data from umusic.com, a website of [[Universal Music Group]].<ref name=viacom>{{cite news|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=Anonymous 'AntiSec' Operation Targets Viacom, Universal Music|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2387893,00.asp|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[PC Magazine]]|date=30 June 2011|agency=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxURLlJT|archivedate=5 July 2011}}</ref> They also released the names of 2,800 members of the [[Black Eagles]] paramilitary group.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=Operation Anti-Security: Anonymous release the identities of 2800 Columbian Black Eagles Special Police Unit members|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/169177/20110624/anonymous-black-eagles-columbia-drug-trafficking-operation-anti-security-lulzsec-hack-hacker-data-da.htm|accessdate=6 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=24 June 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxrTJzBb|archivedate=6 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref>
===July 2011=== On 1 July, Anonymous once again targeted Arizona law enforcement by publishing a number of [[Backdoor (computing)|backdoors]] that could be used to access Arizona police servers to [[Pastebin]]. Arizona was forced to pull many websites offline for a time.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=As LulzSec disband Anonymous continues re-targeting Arizona law enforcement in the name of Operation Anti-Security|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/172761/20110701/lulzsec-anonymous-hackers-hack-arizona-operation-anti-security-cyber-attack-disband-quit.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=1 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zwEwc1It|archivedate=5 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> Websites affected included those of the Department of Public Safety and Mariposa chapter of the Fraternal Order of Police. They also claimed to have found "anti-[[Muslim]]" emails during the attack.<ref>{{cite news|last=Shaer|first=Matthew|title=Anonymous temporarily brings down Arizona police websites|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Innovation/Horizons/2011/0701/Anonymous-temporarily-brings-down-Arizona-police-websites|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=1 July 2011|agency=[[Christian Science Publishing Society]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxTqqRMG|archivedate=5 July 2011|location=[[Boston]]}}</ref>
On 3 July, Anonymous hacked into the database of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] of [[Orange County, Florida]]. They published a partial membership list and a handbook for precinct committee members. The hack was also considered part of the group's OpOrlando plan.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Drew|title=Anonymous Posts Internal Data of the Orange County Democrats|url=http://www.zeropaid.com/news/94103/anonymous-posts-internal-data-of-the-orange-county-democrats/|accessdate=6 July 2011|newspaper=Zeropaid|date=3 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxppc1WY|archivedate=6 July 2011}}</ref>
On 4 July, Anonymous released a document containing 27 administrative usernames and passwords from an [[Apple Inc.]] system used to operate online [[technical support]] follow-up surveys.<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Grady|first=Jason|title=AntiSec posts passwords from Apple survey server (updated 5x)|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/apple/antisec-posts-passwords-from-apple-survey-server-updated-5x/10498|accessdate=6 July 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=3 July 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxoSRQ4X|archivedate=6 July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Yap|first=Jamie|title=Anonymous boasts hack into Apple|url=http://www.zdnetasia.com/anonymous-boasts-hack-into-apple-62301051.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=4 July 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zwCa2OLU|archivedate=5 July 2011}}</ref> The encrypted passwords were taken from an [[SQL]] database.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ribeiro|first=John|title=Hackers Claim Apple Online Data Was Compromised|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/235016/hackers_claim_apple_online_data_was_compromised.html|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[PC Magazine]]|date=4 July 2011|agency=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxHSaqDD|archivedate=5 July 2011}}</ref>
Anonymous launched what it dubbed "Turkish Takedown Thursday" on 6 July. They posted internal data from over one hundred [[.tr]] websites and brought down and replaced the content of 74 of them.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=AntiSec: Anonymous hackers strike again in "Turkish Takedown Thursday"|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/175785/20110707/antisec-anonymous-hackers-turkey-hack-operation-anti-security-internet-lulzsec-redhack.htm|accessdate=7 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=7 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/600MAKvp4|archivedate=7 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> The 74 sites had their normal pages replaced with an Antisec logo and a message denouncing supposed attempts at internet censorship by the Turkish government.<ref>{{cite news|last=Morse|first=Andrew|title=Hackers Claim Attack On Turkish Government Defaces 74 Websites|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110706-714107.html|accessdate=7 July 2011|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=6 July 2011|author2=Ian Sherr|agency=[[Dow Jones & Company]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/600MaGaoi|archivedate=7 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> Websites affected included that of a children's hospital, but not of any key government agencies.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ribeiro|first=John|title=Anonymous Attacks Turkish Websites Again|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/235184/anonymous_attacks_turkish_websites_again.html|accessdate=7 July 2011|newspaper=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|date=7 July 2011|agency=[[International Data Group|IDG]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/600MMQBhX|archivedate=7 July 2011}}</ref> On the same day, the group released database dumps taken from 20 universities in [[Italy]]. Two days later, Italian police arrested 15 alleged members of Anonymous ranging in age from 15 to 28. The group vowed revenge for the raids.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bright|first=Peter|title=Anonymous vows revenge after 15 arrested; AntiSec hacks continue|url=https://arstechnica.com/security/news/2011/07/anonymous-vows-revenge-after-15-arrested-in-italy-antisec-hacks-continue.ars|accessdate=9 July 2011|newspaper=[[Ars Technica]]|date=8 July 2011|agency=[[Condé Nast Publications]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/602Ye82uv|archivedate=9 July 2011}}</ref>
On 8 July, the group claimed responsibility for hacks against IRC Federal, an [[engineering]] firm that contracts with the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] and other agencies of the [[United States federal government]]. Internal database documents and personnel email were stolen during the attack. The group also claimed to have vandalized the firm's website and forcing them to take it offline. The group says that in the documents procured, they found a proposal to the FBI for the firm to produce a "Special Identities Modernization (SIM) Project" that would help identify those who might present a criminal or terrorist risk in the future, [[fingerprinting]] contracts with the [[United States Department of Justice]], and [[biometrics]] contracts with the military.<ref>{{cite news|last=Richmond|first=Riva|title=AntiSec Hackers Hit F.B.I. Contractor|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/08/antisec-hackers-hit-f-b-i-contractor/|accessdate=9 July 2011|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=8 July 2011|agency=[[The New York Times Company]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/602Zp5ELH|archivedate=9 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> They also claimed to have obtained information allowing them to log into various [[virtual private network]]s and access panels belonging to the [[United States Department of Energy]]. They also sent a message to company employees urging them to work against the government rather than for it.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hackers attack another FBI 'partner'|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/225760/technology/hackers-attack-another-fbi-partner|accessdate=9 July 2011|newspaper=[[GMA News TV]]|date=9 July 2011|agency=[[GMA Network, Inc.]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/602ahab4Y|archivedate=9 July 2011|location=[[Quezon City]]}}</ref> The hack was done with a simple [[SQL injection]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Bright|first=Peter|title=AntiSec target learns the hard way that whitelists > blacklists|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/07/antisec-target-learns-the-hard-way-that-whitelists-blacklists.ars|accessdate=12 July 2011|newspaper=[[Ars Technica]]|date=11 July 2011|agency=[[Condé Nast Digital]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/606wALZ5b|archivedate=12 July 2011}}</ref>
On 11 July, Anonymous hacked into systems belonging to [[defense contractor]] [[Booz Allen Hamilton]], breaking through barriers that the group described as having "no security measures in place." They released what they said were 90,000 email accounts and encrypted passwords from [[United States Central Command]], [[United States Special Operations Command]], the [[United States Marine Corps]], the [[United States Air Force]], the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]], [[United States Department of State]], and various private sector contractors, calling the released "Military Meltdown Monday".<ref>{{cite news|last=Gerwirtz|first=David|title=Military Meltdown Monday: 90,000 military email profiles released by AntiSec|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/government/military-meltdown-monday-90000-military-email-profiles-released-by-antisec/10580|accessdate=12 July 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=11 July 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/606teMhkF|archivedate=12 July 2011}}</ref><ref name=compworld>{{cite news|last=Storm|first=Darlene|title=AntiSec hackers mangle & pwn defense contractor, leak Booz Allen Hamilton's data|url=http://blogs.computerworld.com/18607/antisec_hackers_mangle_pwn_defense_contractor_leak_booz_allen_hamiltons_data?source=rss_blogs|accessdate=12 July 2011|newspaper=[[Computerworld]]|date=11 July 2011|agency=[[International Data Group]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/606uq0mhw|archivedate=12 July 2011}}</ref> They also sarcastically posted an invoice charging the company for "security audit services rendered".<ref name=compworld/> Despite Anonymous' claims that 90,000 emails were released, the [[Associated Press]] counted only 67,000 unique emails, of which only 53,000 were military addresses. The remainder of the addresses came from educational institutions and defense contractors.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hennigan|first=W.J.|title=Hacking group AntiSec says it stole 90,000 U.S. military email passwords|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/technology/2011/07/booz-allen-hamilton-antisec-hacked.html|accessdate=12 July 2011|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=11 July 2011|agency=[[Tribune Company]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6076G8dc1|archivedate=12 July 2011|location=[[Los Angeles]]}}</ref> The Department of Defense said they were aware of the incident and were coordinating with other agencies for a response.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stray|first=Jonathan|title=Hackers target top contractor, nab passwords|url=http://www.airforcetimes.com/news/2011/07/ap-data-breach-booze-allen-hamilton-hackers-071111/|accessdate=12 July 2011|newspaper=[[Air Force Times]]|date=11 July 2011|agency=[[Gannett Government Media]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6076UtgwT|archivedate=12 July 2011|location=[[Springfield, Virginia]]}}</ref> Booz Allen confirmed the intrusion on 13 July, but contradicted Anonymous' claims in saying that the attack never got past their own systems, meaning that information from the military should be secure.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=AntiSec: Booz Allen Hamilton Confirm Anonymous Hacker Raid's Authenticity|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/179145/20110713/anonymous-hackers-hack-hacked-booz-allen-hamilton-military-passwords-emails-boom.htm|accessdate=13 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=13 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/609N7FW7E|archivedate=13 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref>
On 12 July, the group attacked the web servers of [[agricultural biotechnology]] company [[Monsanto]] and released information on the company's employees, including names, addresses, and email addresses. The group claimed they performed the attack to protest the company's lawsuits against farmers who manufacture [[organic milk]] in an effort to stop them from stating on the label that their milk does not contain artificial [[Bovine Growth Hormone]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mills|first=Elinor|title=Anonymous targets Monsanto, oil firms|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-27080_3-20078963-245/anonymous-targets-monsanto-oil-firms/|accessdate=13 July 2011|newspaper=[[CNET]]|date=12 July 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/609MuXsHa|archivedate=13 July 2011}}</ref> Monsanto confirmed the attack but claimed that only about ten percent of the information published came from current or former employees of the company. They said that the other ninety percent were email addresses and names of media contacts and employees of other agricultural companies.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mills|first=Elinor|title=Monsanto confirms Anonymous hacking attack|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-27080_3-20079233-245/monsanto-confirms-anonymous-hacking-attack/|accessdate=13 July 2011|newspaper=[[CNET]]|date=13 July 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=http://news.cnet.com/8301-27080_3-20079233-245/monsanto-confirms-anonymous-hacking-attack/|archivedate=13 July 2011}}</ref>
On 21 July, Anonymous released two [[PDF]]s purportedly taken from servers belonging to [[NATO]]. They claimed via Twitter to have obtained around one gigabyte of data that they would release portions of over the course of a few days. The group claimed that some of the data was so sensitive that they felt it would be irresponsible to release, and thus would only make a portion of what was taken available. The first two documents released relate to outsourcing [[Information and communications technology|communication and information services]] (CIS) in [[Kosovo]] and the funding request for the project.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=Anonymous Hackers Hit NATO: One Gigabyte of Military Data Lost|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/184354/20110721/anonymous-hackers-sabu-nato-hack-news-release-data-military-security-antisec-anti.htm|accessdate=21 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=21 July 2011|archiveurl=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/184354/20110721/anonymous-hackers-sabu-nato-hack-news-release-data-military-security-antisec-anti.htm|archivedate=12 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=[[Associated Press]]|title='Anonymous' Hackers Claim to Breach NATO Security|url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2011/07/21/anonymous-hackers-claim-to-breach-nato-security/|accessdate=21 July 2011|newspaper=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=21 July 2011|agency=[[News Corporation]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60LNWDWvw|archivedate=12 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref>
The [[Austria]]n branch of Anonymous hacked the website of the Austrian Gebühren Info Service, the television license agency run by [[ORF (broadcaster)|the Austrian national public service broadcaster]], on 22 July. They accessed 214,000 records containing personal information and stole the banking data of 96,000 people from the server. The counter-terrorism bureau of the country launched an investigation and were preparing to file criminal complaints against those involved.<ref>{{cite news|title='Anonymous' hackers access Austrian bank data|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hNfDbHdyCCM-d4v6wJMrYqhHx87A?docId=CNG.2b17a77189556ccd97e4abe61a3f838c.b61|accessdate=25 July 2011|newspaper=[[Associated Press]]|date=25 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60RmBVBhO|archivedate=25 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref>
On 25 July, first posted confidential information that they claimed came from the [[Italy|Italian]] Centro Nazionale Anticrimine Informatico per la Protezione delle Infrastrutture Critiche, translated as the National Anti-Crime Computer Center for Critical Infrastructure Protection, an agency tasked with protecting vital computer systems for the country. The Twitter account @anonesc posted less than 100 megabytes of data, but they claimed to have taken over eight gigabytes. The data related to [[oil company|oil]], [[nuclear power|nuclear]], and other firms deemed to be involved in "critical infrastructure", as well as government agencies including the [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]] of [[Australia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Hackers post documents from Italian cybercrime unit|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/internet/8660683/Hackers-post-documents-from-Italian-cybercrime-unit.html|accessdate=25 July 2011|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=25 July 2011|agency=Telegraph Media Group|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60RlZijmZ|archivedate=25 July 2011|location=[[London]]}}</ref>
On 29 July, Anonymous hacked the FBI-contractor [[ManTech International]]. They posted a PDF of a [[résumé]] sent into the company as proof that they had infiltrated their systems. Anonymous claimed that the attack would be the first part of a promised "Fuck FBI Friday", or FFF, campaign as part of the larger Operation AntiSec.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=Anonymous Target U.S. Security Contractor: FBI Release Promised|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/189062/20110729/anonymous-target-fbi-release-arrest-arrests-hackers-military-nato-man-tech-data-lulzsec-antisec-payp.htm|accessdate=29 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=29 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60Y2khcY2|archivedate=29 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> They published 400 megabytes of content from the company later the same day. The internal documents generally concern contracts that ManTech has with NATO, the nature of which Anonymous claims shows a waste of [[Public funds|taxpayer money]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Hachman|first=Mark|title=Anonymous Publishes Internal Documents from Govt. Contractor ManTech|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2389447,00.asp|accessdate=29 July 2011|newspaper=[[PC Magazine]]|date=29 July 2011|agency=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60YBXcsZq|archivedate=29 July 2011}}</ref> The files also include dealings with the [[United States Army]] and a list of employee emails.<ref>{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Andy|title=Undeterred By Arrests, Anonymous Spills Data From FBI Contractor ManTech|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/andygreenberg/2011/07/29/undeterred-by-arrests-anonymous-spills-data-from-fbi-contractor-mantech/|accessdate=29 July 2011|newspaper=[[Forbes Magazine]]|date=29 July 2011|agency=[[Forbes]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60YBloLwh|archivedate=29 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref>
On 31 July, Anonymous attacked the websites of 77 different [[law enforcement]] websites hosted on the same server. As much as 10 gigabytes of data was taken, including the personal information of police officers from numerous jurisdictions. Emails were also taken, as well as the confidential information of inmates and [[confidential informant]]s, though not released yet. Anonymous said that they would redact inmate names but would release the names of all " informants who had the false impression that they would be able to ‘anonymously’ snitch in secrecy." The release also included a demand that all arrested members of Anonymous be released immediately.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ragan|first=Steve|title=AntiSec: 77 law enforcement websites hit in mass attack|url=http://www.thetechherald.com/article.php/201130/7447/AntiSec-77-law-enforcement-websites-hit-in-mass-attack|accessdate=31 July 2011|newspaper=[[The Tech Herald]]|date=31 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60a68a3Rm|archivedate=31 July 2011}}</ref> Some of the information released, however, was already publicly available.<ref>{{cite news|last=David|first=Brennan|title=Hackers crash sheriffs’ association website: Carey Says Most Info was Public|url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/news/2011/aug/01/hackers-crash-sheriffs-association-website/|accessdate=1 August 2011|newspaper=[[Columbia Daily Tribune]]|date=1 August 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60cfzywod|archivedate=1 August 2011|location=[[Columbia, Missouri]]}}</ref> They proceeded to release the [[social security number]]s of over 100 police officers from the Missouri Sheriffs' Association website.<ref>{{cite news|last=Usigan|first=Ysolt|title=Online security breach! Hackers leak social security numbers of cops in Missouri|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-501465_162-20087410-501465.html|accessdate=5 August 2011|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=3 August 2011|agency=[[CBS]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60hTXTzzU|archivedate=5 August 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> The following Saturday, 6 August, they released a cache of data from the websites title "Shooting Sheriffs Saturday Release" which included the information taken from law enforcement websites. Large amounts of personal information was included, with Anonymous stating, "We have no sympathy for any of the officers or informants who may be endangered by the release of their personal information. For too long they have been using and abusing our personal information."<ref name=ccn>{{cite news|last=Mills|first=Elinor|title=AntiSec hackers post stolen police data as revenge for arrests|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-27080_3-20089054-245/antisec-hackers-post-stolen-police-data-as-revenge-for-arrests/|accessdate=6 August 2011|newspaper=[[CNET]]|date=6 August 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60jwqabgh|archivedate=6 August 2011}}</ref> Anonymous claimed that their motive was revenge over the arrests of a number of participants in previous operations and of LulzSec and Anonymous member [[Topiary (hacktivist)|Topiary]]. They also used stolen [[credit card number]]s to make donations to the [[American Civil Liberties Union]], [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]], and the [[Chelsea Manning]] Support Network.<ref name=ccn/>
===August 2011=== On 16 August, Anonymous gained access to the email account of Richard Garcia, former Assistant Director in Charge of the FBI field office in [[Los Angeles]] and [[Senior Vice President]] of Vanguard Defense Industries, in the name of AntiSec. They claimed that the firm's relationships with United States military and law enforcement organizations made it a legitimate target as part of the operation. They also claimed to have breached the company's website, which was run on a [[WordPress]] platform, though the company says that their website was never affected.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ragan|first=Steve|title=Vanguard Defense Industries compromised by AntiSec|url=http://www.thetechherald.com/article.php/201133/7514/Vanguard-Defense-Industries-compromised-by-AntiSec|accessdate=18 August 2011|newspaper=[[The Tech Herald]]|date=16 August 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/612Cy17OA|archivedate=18 August 2011|page=1}}</ref> The group released 1 gigabyte of information three days later, all of it taken from Garcia's personal email account; it mainly related to Garcia's former role with InfraGard.<ref>{{cite news|last=Skillings|first=Jonathan|title=AntiSec hackers target Vanguard Defense exec|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-1009_3-20094621-83/antisec-hackers-target-vanguard-defense-exec/|accessdate=19 August 2011|newspaper=[[CNET]]|date=19 August 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/613tYmgRK|archivedate=19 August 2011}}</ref>
===September 2011=== In retaliation for arrests of people who allegedly participated in Operation AntiSec, and especially [[Topiary (hacktivist)|Topiary]], Anonymous attacked the website of the Texas Police Chiefs Association. On 1 September, the group defaced the website and released documents from it marked "law enforcement sensitive" and "for official use only". The release also included police officer private email. The same day, the group brought down the website of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] for the justice system's characterization of Anonymous activities as "cyber-terrorism".<ref>{{cite news|last=Ribeiro|first=John|title=Anonymous Claims Hack of Texas Police Website|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/239407/anonymous_claims_hack_of_texas_police_website.html|accessdate=5 September 2011|newspaper=[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]|date=2 September 2011|agency=[[International Data Group|IDG]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61TbdSoz8|archivedate=5 September 2011}}</ref>
===October 2011=== On 21 October, announced a dump of data related to law enforcement in support of the [[Occupy Wall Street]] and [["Occupy" protests|Occupy movement]]. The dump including data taken from the [[International Association of Chiefs of Police]], Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, and the Sheriff's office of [[Baldwin County, Alabama]]. A number of police websites [[Virtual hosting|virtually hosted]] together also had their content replaced with an anti-police [[rap]] video.<ref name=recent>{{cite news|last=Norton|first=Quinn|title=Anonymous and Antisec Attack Law Enforcement Websites|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/10/anonymous-law-enforcement/|accessdate=22 October 2011|newspaper=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=22 October 2011|agency=[[Condé Nast Publications]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62clufdSd|archivedate=22 October 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> The dump 600 megabytes of information including membership rosters, internal documents, and social security numbers from the International Association of Chiefs of Police; nearly 1000 names, ranks, addresses, phone numbers, and social security numbers of police officers in [[Jefferson County, Alabama]] and [[Birmingham, Alabama]]; 1000 names and passwords of members of the Boston Police Patrolmen's Association; and the financial information and client list of web developer and marketing company Matrix Group, a business with several law enforcement clients.<ref name=recent/><ref>{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=Meghan|title=Anonymous releases private police information in name of Occupy Wall Street|url=https://venturebeat.com/2011/10/21/anonymous-occupy-wall-street-police/|accessdate=22 October 2011|newspaper=[[VentureBeat]]|date=21 October 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62cmjqf6W|archivedate=22 October 2011}}</ref> AntiSec claimed that at least 40 law enforcement related websites were included in the attack.<ref>{{cite news|last=Guilfoil|first=John|title=Online political hacker group hits Boston police websites|url=http://www.boston.com/Boston/metrodesk/2011/10/hacker-group-hits-boston-police-websites/dZ2bbt28EWyFXuYTlkYqRK/index.html|accessdate=22 October 2011|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=22 October 2011|agency=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[Boston]]}}</ref>
===November 2011=== On November 18, 2011, Anonymous posted 38,000 email messages from the [[Gmail]] account of Alfredo "Fred" Baclagan, a special agent supervising computer crime investigations with the [[California Department of Justice]] and the Computer and Technology Crime Hightech Response Team, to a site on [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]] and to [[The Pirate Bay]].<ref name=alfredo>{{cite news|last=Gallagher|first=Sean|title=Anonymous exposes cybercrime investigator's Gmail, voicemail|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/11/anonymous-exposes-cybercrime-investigators-gmail-voicemail.ars|accessdate=29 November 2011|newspaper=[[Ars Technica]]|date=21 November 2011|agency=[[Condé Nast Publications]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63Z7qwQBQ|archivedate=29 November 2011}}</ref><ref name=Quinn>{{cite news|last=Norton|first=Quinn|title=Anonymous Hacks Back at Cybercrime Investigators|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/11/anonymous-hacks-forensics/|accessdate=29 November 2011|newspaper=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|date=19 November 2011|agency=[[Condé Nast Publications]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63Z8voOjO|archivedate=29 November 2011}}</ref> They also added what they claimed were Baclagan's personal home address and phone number. The group claimed the action as part of their attack on law enforcement in support of the Occupy movement and in protest for prosecution of computer criminals in general. They also claimed to have read his text messages, listened to his voicemail, and used his [[Google Voice]] account to call and text his friends and family.<ref name=alfredo/> They also purchased a camera using his [[Google Wallet]].<ref name=Quinn/> The release includes [[Forensic science|forensic]] experts discussing techniques for tracking cybercriminals and how different companies respond to law enforcement requests for information.<ref name=Quinn/>
=== September 2012 ===
<!-- I think this was on 4 September, but someone should probably confirm this. This is when the story broke. -->On 4 September 2012, 1 million unique device IDs for Apple products were published by a group associated with Anonymous.<ref name="fbihack-aje">{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/americas/2012/09/201294155021237214.html|title=Hackers claim 12 million Apple IDs from FBI|accessdate=5 September 2012|author=Al Jazeera English}}</ref> The group claimed that the 1 million IDs were part of a dataset of 12.36 million records taken from an FBI laptop.<ref name="fbihack-aje" /> The FBI responded by saying they were not aware of any unauthorized data release.<ref name="fbihack-guardianuk">{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2012/sep/04/fbi-denies-apple-id-hacking|title=FBI denies hacking group AntiSec obtained Apple IDs from federal laptop|accessdate=5 September 2012|author=''The Guardian'' (UK)|location=London|date=4 September 2012}}</ref>
According to an [[Ars Technica]] article published on September 10: <blockquote>A digital publishing company named BlueToad has come forward to take responsibility for the leak of a million iOS unique device identifiers (UDIDs) that were previously attributed to an alleged FBI laptop hack. In a number of interviews published Monday, BlueToad apologized to the public for the incident, explaining that hackers had broken into the company's systems in order to steal the file.<ref>Jacqui Cheng. Publishing firm: iOS UDID leak came from us, not the FBI. Ars Technica. . URL:https://arstechnica.com/apple/2012/09/publishing-firm-ios-udid-leak-came-from-us-not-the-fbi/. Accessed: 2012-09-11. (Archived by WebCite® at https://www.webcitation.org/6AbiVQb5F)</ref></blockquote>
==Actions by other groups and individuals== The original announcement of Operation Anti-Security included a call from LulzSec to spread the name "AntiSec" through physical [[graffiti]].<ref name=USAToday/> A few days after, a number of locations in [[Mission Beach, San Diego]] were vandalized with pieces of graffiti reading the phrase.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gayathri|first=Amrutha|title=Operation Anti-Security: Mysterious serial graffiti reported; LulzSec gaining mass support?|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/166507/20110621/operation-anti-security-mysterious-serial-graffiti-reported-lulzsec-gaining-mass-support-anonymous-h.htm|accessdate=21 June 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=21 June 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zbDnFq7t|archivedate=21 June 2011|location=New York City}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title="Anti-Sec" group spreads message through graffiti in Mission Beach|url=http://www.cbs8.com/story/14941495/anti-sec-group-spreads-message-through-graffiti-in-mission-beach?redirected=true|accessdate=21 June 2011|newspaper=CBS 8|date=20 June 2011}}</ref>
On 4 July, a [[Fox News]] Twitter account (@foxnewspolitics) was hacked and false tweets reporting that [[President of the United States]] [[Barack Obama]] has been shot three times and killed were sent from the account.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=Hacked Fox News falsely reports U.S. President Obama Assassinated|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/173863/20110704/fox-news-hacked-president-obama-dead-killed-assassinated-shot-assassins-hackers-target-4-july.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=4 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zwTo8Osc|archivedate=5 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> The [[Script Kiddies (group)|Script Kiddies]], a group with close ties to Anonymous including two hackers with former membership in the group, claimed responsibility for the attack and hoax. The group claimed that the action was in the name of Operation Anti-Security and that they would continue looking to expose information on corporations "to assist with antisec."<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=Hacked Fox News Obama assassination hoax done in the name of Anonymous' Operation Anti-Security|url=http://uk.ibtimes.com/articles/173982/20110704/fox-news-hacked-president-obama-dead-killed-assassinated-script-kiddies-anonymous-shot-assassins-hac.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=4 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zwU5dDmQ|archivedate=5 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> The [[United States Secret Service]] is investigating the incident as a threat on the President.<ref>{{cite news|last=MacInnis|first=Laura|title=Hackers falsely claim Obama dead on Fox Twitter feed|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/sns-rt-us-media-twitter-hatre7642p9-20110705,0,5074886.story|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=5 July 2011|agency=[[Tribune Company]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxSkpnZg|archivedate=5 July 2011|location=[[Los Angeles]]}}</ref> The group subsequently hacked into the [[Facebook]] page of pharmaceutical company [[Pfizer]], claiming they did so for "moral reasons" as part of AntiSec.<ref>{{cite web|last=Brewster|first=Tom|title=The AntiSec campaign rumbles on with a new group going under the moniker of the Script Kiddies joining in|url=http://www.itpro.co.uk/635131/pfizer-s-facebook-hacked-in-antisec-hit|work=IT Pro|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]]|accessdate=25 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60RdAbFof|archivedate=25 July 2011|date=22 July 2011}}</ref> They posted numerous messages to the company's Facebook wall mocking their security.<ref>{{cite news|last=Danchev|first=Dancho|title=Pfizer's Facebook hacked by AntiSec|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/security/pfizers-facebook-hacked-by-antisec/9113|accessdate=28 July 2011|newspaper=[[ZDNet]]|date=27 July 2011|agency=[[CBS Interactive]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60VMVXrze|archivedate=28 July 2011}}</ref>
On 4 July, someone going by the name f1esc posted a file to [[The Pirate Bay]] containing 600 megabytes of information described as national "AU election data" and labelled with the tag #Antisec. In reality, the data concerned the [[New South Wales state election, 2011|2011 New South Wales state election]] and was taken from a government website designed to provide election results where the data was publicly available, and the data proved freely accessible information instead of a hack.<ref>{{cite news|last=Chirgwin|first=Richard|title=Operation Antisec lames out again: Public data posted in Pirate Bay facepalm|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/07/04/when_is_a_leak_not_a_leak/|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=[[The Register]]|date=4 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxHCVYIi|archivedate=5 July 2011}}</ref>
In early July, the group RedHack hacked into and defaced over 1000 websites based in Turkey. They claimed to do so both to mark the anniversary of the [[Sivas massacre]] and as part of Operation Anti-Security. The websites belonged both to agencies of the [[Government of Turkey]] and [[Adnan Oktar]], an Islamic [[creationist]]. The group vowed to continue contribution to the AntiSec operation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stevenson|first=Alastair|title=AntiSec hacking Boom: On the anniversary of the Sivas Katliamı Anonymous and allies RedHack deface 1000 websites|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/174362/20110705/anonymous-redhack-turkey-sivas-katliam-massacre-adnan-oktar-websites-hack-1000-protest.htm|accessdate=7 July 2011|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=5 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6007popF2|archivedate=7 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref>
On 6 July, a hacker called p0keu released of around 2,658 usernames, passwords hidden behind [[cryptographic hash function|hash functions]], and email addresses from the [[blog]] TamilCanadian.com. He gave no reason for why he chose the website to attack other than that he did so under the AntiSec label.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Drew|title=P0keu Dumps Usernames and Passwords of TamilCanadian.com to Pastebin|url=http://www.zeropaid.com/news/94214/p0keu-dumps-usernames-and-passwords-of-tamilcanadian-com-to-pastebin/|accessdate=16 July 2011|newspaper=Zeropaid|date=6 July 2011|archiveurl=http://www.zeropaid.com/news/94214/p0keu-dumps-usernames-and-passwords-of-tamilcanadian-com-to-pastebin/|archivedate=16 July 2011}}</ref> On 14 July, he leaked part of the [[Stevens Institute of Technology]] website database. At least 31 of the records in the database contained plain [[text file]]s with email addresses, user names, and passwords of site users. p0keu posted the user information to Pastebin.<ref>{{cite news|last=Purcell|first=Joe|title=237,234 Records Breached: Operation AntiSec Continues, Operation Green Rights Begins|url=http://www.securitypronews.com/insiderreports/insider/spn-49-20110714237234RecordsBreachedOperationAntiSecContinuesOperationGreenRightsBegins.html|accessdate=15 July 2011|newspaper=Security Pro News|date=14 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60CHVHG44|archivedate=15 July 2011}}</ref> p0keu has continued hacking, but has not labelled all of his releases with the AntiSec slogan.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wilson|first=Drew|title=P0keu Hacks Eastern District Court of Tennessee Website, Passwords Exposed|url=http://www.zeropaid.com/news/94409/p0keu-hacks-eastern-district-court-of-tennessee-website-passwords-exposed/|accessdate=18 July 2011|newspaper=Zeropaid|date=17 July 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60HKy9MVT|archivedate=18 July 2011}}</ref>
In the [[Netherlands]], a splinter group inspired by LulzSec formed, calling themselves AntiSec NL. The group hacked into the websites of [[online dating service]] [[pepper.nl]] and software company [[Nimbuzz]]. Four people believed by police to be members were later arrested.<ref name=nl>{{cite news|last=Sterling|first=Toby|title=Dutch give details on 4 'Anonymous' hacker arrests|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-technology/dutch-give-details-on-4-anonymous-hacker-arrests-20110721-1hp9g.html|accessdate=21 July 2011|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=21 July 2011|agency=[[Fairfax Media]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60Lj08HZB|archivedate=21 July 2011|location=[[Sydney]]}}</ref>
On 24 July, a group called [[BashCrew]] hacked the website of the [[House of Representatives of the Philippines]] in the name of AntiSec. The names, telephone numbers, and email addresses of members of the Filipino Congress were released via Pastebin, with the group claiming that they may also release blood types and the private websites of some members.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hackers hit Congress website on eve of SONA|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/227276/technology/hackers-hit-congress-website-on-eve-of-sona|accessdate=25 July 2011|newspaper=[[GMA News TV]]|date=24 July 2011|agency=[[GMA Network, Inc.]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60RdeaVZx|archivedate=25 July 2011|location=[[Quezon City]]}}</ref>
A hacker going by the name Thehacker12, a self-purported AntiSec supporter but not a member of Anonymous, released data stolen from [[event management]] company allianceforbiz.com on 24 August 2011 on Mediafire and Pastebin. The release contained a [[spreadsheet]] of usernames, email addresses, passwords, employers, and other information of around 20,000 people, many of them United States government employees or contractors. The organization with the most employees compromised was the [[Small Business Administration]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Rashid|first=Fahmida|title=Cyber-Attacker Dumps Log-ins for 20,000 Customers, U.S. Employees|url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Security/CyberAttacker-Dumps-Logins-for-20000-Customers-US-Employees-340799/|accessdate=25 August 2011|newspaper=[[eWeek]]|date=24 August 2011|agency=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/61CK2x2oY|archivedate=25 August 2011}}</ref>
==Law enforcement response== Law enforcement agencies in various countries have arrested or searched the property of alleged participants in Operation AntiSec. These suspects have come from different groups who carried out attacks as part of the operation. On 19 July 2011, the London Metropolitan Police announced the arrest of possible core LulzSec member T-flow. A 16-year-old male was arrested in South London on charges of violating the Computer Misuse Act as part of an operation involving the arrest of several other hackers affiliated with Anonymous in the United States and United Kingdom.<ref name=tflow>{{cite news|last=Kaplan|first=Jeremy|title=Leading Member of LulzSec Hacker Squad Arrested in London|url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2011/07/19/leading-member-lulzsec-hacker-squad-arrested-in-london/|accessdate=20 July 2011|newspaper=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=19 July 2011|agency=[[News Corporation]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60J70ybQ5|archivedate=20 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Greenberg|first=Andy|title=Hacker Arrests May Have Included Core Member Of LulzSec|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/andygreenberg/2011/07/19/hacker-arrests-may-have-included-core-member-of-lulzsec/|accessdate=20 July 2011|newspaper=[[Forbes]]|date=19 July 2011|agency=Forbes Publishing|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60J6iInOP|archivedate=20 July 2011|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> On the same day, the FBI arrested 21-year-old Lance Moore in [[Las Cruces, New Mexico]]. He was accused of stealing thousands of documents and applications from AT&T that LulzSec published as part of their so-called "final release" of the operation. LulzSec denied that any of their membership had been arrested, stating "there are six of us, and we're all still here."<ref name=nl/>
On 20 July, prosecutors in the Netherlands released details of the arrests of four suspects aged 17, 18, 25, and 35. All were located in different Dutch cities and accused of being part of the hacking group AntiSec NL, an operation participant inspired by LulzSec. The four, going by the online handles Ziaolin, Calimero, DutchD3V1L, and Time, were arrested on 19 July and their computers and electronic equipment confiscated as evidence. Prosecutors identified the suspects after computer security company Fox-IT helped them gain access to a chat channel thought to be used by the group.<ref name=nl/>
The [[Police National E-Crime Unit|Police Central E-Crime Unit]] arrested an 18-year-old man from [[Shetland]] on 27 July 2011 suspected of being LulzSec member [[Topiary (hacktivist)|Topiary]]. They also searched the house of and interviewed a 17-year-old from [[Lincolnshire]] possibly connected to the investigation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Man arrested over computer hacking claims|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14315442|accessdate=27 July 2011|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=27 July 2011|agency=[[BBC]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60V2b9j2F|archivedate=27 July 2011|location=[[London]]}}</ref> Scotland Yard later identified the man arrested as [[Yell, Shetland]] resident Jake Davis. He was charged with unauthorized access of a computer under the [[Computer Misuse Act 1990]], encouraging or assisting criminal activity under the [[Serious Crime Act 2007]], conspiracy to launch a denial-of-service attack against the Serious Organised Crime Unit contrary to the [[Criminal Law Act 1977]], and [[criminal conspiracy]] also under the Criminal Law Act 1977.<ref name=topiaryid>{{cite news|last=Albanesius|first=Chloe|title=Report: Scotland Yard Identifies LulzSec Hacker|url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2389486,00.asp|accessdate=31 July 2011|newspaper=[[PC Magazine]]|date=31 July 2011|agency=[[Ziff Davis]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60b797m4U|archivedate=31 July 2011}}</ref> Police confiscated a [[Dell]] laptop and a 100-gigabyte hard drive that ran 16 different [[virtual machine]]s. Details relating to an attack on Sony and hundreds of thousands of email addresses and passwords were found on the computer.<ref name=topiarybail>{{cite news|last=Prodhan|first=Georgina|title=UK teen cyber activist bailed without Internet access|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/08/01/us-britain-hacking-anonymous-idUSTRE7702HH20110801|accessdate=1 August 2011|newspaper=[[Reuters]]|date=1 August 2011|agency=[[Thomson Reuters]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60cfULJNm|archivedate=1 August 2011|location=[[London]]}}</ref> A London court released Davis on bail under the conditions that he live under curfew with his parents and have no access to the internet. His lawyer Gideon Cammerman stated that, while his client did help publicize LulzSec and Anonymous attacks, he lacks the technical skills to have been anything but a sympathizer.<ref name=topiarybail/>
In early September 2011, Scotland Yard made two further arrests relating to LulzSec. Police arrested a 24-year-old male in [[Mexborough]], [[South Yorkshire]] and a 20-year-old male in [[Warminster]], [[Wiltshire]]. The two are accused of conspiring to commit offenses under the Computer Misuse Act of 1990; police said that the arrests related to investigations into LulzSec member Kayla.<ref>{{cite news|title=LulzSec and Anonymous police and FBI investigation sees two more arrested|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2011/sep/02/lulzsec-anonymous-two-more-arrests|accessdate=2 September 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=2 September 2011|agency=[[Guardian Media Group]]|location=[[London]]}}</ref>
On 6 March 2012, two men from Great Britain, one from the United States, and two from [[Ireland]] were charged in connection to their alleged involvement with LulzSec. The FBI revealed that supposed LulzSec leader Hector Xavier Monsegur, who went by the username Sabu, had been aiding law enforcement since pleading guilty to twelve counts, including conspiracy and computer hacking, on 15 August 2011 as part of a [[plea deal]].<ref name=Sabufox>{{cite news|last=Winter|first=Jana|title=Infamous international hacking group LulzSec brought down by own leader|url=http://www.foxnews.com/scitech/2012/03/06/hacking-group-lulzsec-swept-up-by-law-enforcement/|accessdate=13 March 2012|newspaper=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=6 March 2012|agency=[[News Corporation]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/668lsO0Fu|archivedate=13 March 2012|location=[[New York City]]}}</ref> In exchange for his cooperation, federal prosecutors agreed not to prosecute Monsegur for his computer hacking, and also not to prosecute him for two attempts to sell [[marijuana]], possession of an illegal handgun, purchasing stolen property, charging $15,000 to his former employer's credit card in a case of [[identity theft]], and directing people to buy prescription drugs from illegal sources. He still faces a misdemeanor charge of [[police impersonation|impersonating a federal agent]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Caruso|first=David B.|title=Feds: NYC hacker also involved with drug dealing|url=http://www.boston.com/business/technology/articles/2012/03/09/feds_nyc_hacker_also_involved_with_drug_dealing/?rss_id=Boston+Globe+--+Technology+stories|accessdate=13 March 2012|newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=9 March 2012|author2=Jennifer Peltz|agency=[[The New York Times Company]]|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/668v8fXJB|archivedate=13 March 2012|location=[[Boston]]}}</ref> Five suspects were charged with conspiracy: Jake Davis, accused of being the hacker "Topiary" (who had been previously arrested); Ryan Ackroyd of London, accused of being "Kayla"; Darren Martyn of Ireland, accused of being "pwnsauce"; Donncha O’Cearrbhail of Ireland, accused of being "palladium"; and [[Jeremy Hammond]] of [[Chicago]], accused of being "Anarchaos". While not a member of LulzSec, authorities suspect Hammond of being a member of Anonymous and charged him with access device fraud and hacking in relation to his supposed involvement in the December 2011 attack on intelligence company [[Stratfor]] as part of Operation AntiSec.<ref name=Sabufox/>

'''[[Polygamy]]''' is legal in '''[[Indonesia]]''', the largest [[Muslim]] population in the world. Polygamy in Indonesia is not just practiced by Muslims, but also customarily done by non-Muslim minorities, such as the Balinese and the Papuans.<ref name="Martyn"/><ref name="Courtens"/><ref name="Pickell"/>
A Muslim man may take up to four wives. As allowed by [[Islam]], a man may take more than one wive as long as he treats them equally and can financially support them all. Despite such religious legality, polygamy has faced some of the most intense opposition than any other nation with the majority consisting of Muslims. Recent restrictions have brought about harsher penalties for unlawfully contracted polygamous unions and polygamy is said to be on the decline. Indonesian military personnel are only permitted to practice polygamy if their religion allows it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/08/07/defense-ministry-permits-polygamy.html |title=Defense Ministry permits polygamy |first=The Jakarta |last=Post}}</ref> Additionally, he must prove to the government that his first wife is unable to carry out her duties as a wife.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://genderindex.org/country/indonesia |title=Gender Equality in Indonesia — Social Institutions and Gender Index (SIGI)}}</ref>
Polygamy under [[Balinese Hinduism]] is sanctioned and unrestricted, but the marriage is regulated by ''[[adat]]'' (traditional customs).<ref name="Martyn"/> Although polygamous marriages are practiced in Bali, the nature of Hindu polygamy has not been included in the national marriage law debates.<ref name="Martyn">{{cite book | title = The Women's Movement in Postcolonial Indonesia: Gender and Nation in a New Democracy | first = Elizabeth | last = Martyn | url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=CQh_AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA263&dq=balinese+polygamy&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwin4YHAh7HXAhWBgbwKHYNKCaQQuwUILzAB#v=onepage&q=balinese%20polygamy&f=false | page = 178, 184 | publisher = Routledge | year = 2004 | isbn = 9781134394708 }}</ref> The native inhabitants of [[West Papua (province)|West Papua]] and [[Papua (province)|Papua]] have been practicing polygamy long before the arrival of Christian missionaries.<ref name="Courtens"/><ref name="Pickell">{{cite book | title = Indonesian New Guinea Adventure Guide: West Papua / Irian Jaya | first = David | last = Pickell | url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=9prTAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT56&dq=west+papuan+polygamy&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjYpszYj7HXAhXEabwKHdihB9EQuwUISTAG#v=onepage&q=west%20papuan%20polygamy&f=false | publisher = Tuttle Publishing | year = 2013 | isbn = 9781462909254 }}</ref> The Papuans who choose to still practice polygamous marriages after being Christians usually conduct the ''adat'' marriages instead of the church one.<ref name="Courtens">{{cite book | title = Restoring the Balance: Performing Healing in West Papua | first = Ien | last = Courtens | url = https://books.google.co.id/books?id=qUJlAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA217&dq=west+papuan+polygamy&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiY7tO6kLHXAhUHybwKHUI6Cso4ChC7BQg3MAM#v=onepage&q=west%20papuan%20polygamy&f=false | page = 217 | publisher = BRILL | year = 2008 | isbn = 9789004253902 }}</ref>
On a separate note, a study found that [[polygamous]] politicians are overwhelmingly less likely to gain female votes than [[monogamous]] politicians.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2009/04/01/us-indonesia-polygamy-idINTRE53030G20090401 |title=Polygamous Indonesia politicians may lose female votes}}</ref>
== Complete ban on polygamy == In late April 2008, a rally of Indonesian women led a protest against the nation's laws allowing for polygamy and polygamous marriages; urging the government to enact a complete ban over such marriages. Male Indonesian politicians were found to be largely opposed, and such a ban has yet to take place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/04/23/2225118.htm |title=Indonesian women lobby for polygamy ban |date=23 April 2008}}</ref>
